titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Rainy morning. Walk, to look at the Fair. Took the Haerlem boat at 11. o’clock. Arrived at 3. Dined at Haerlem, and proceeded again in the Boat to Amsterdam where I arrived between 7 and 8 in the Evening. Found at the arms of Amsterdam, W. Lee of Boston, Clark and Tucker; G. Apthorp and a Mr: Bell of New-York. Captain Mackay sent me some newspapers.— Finished reading Rousseau’s Emile, and the supplementary fragment of Emile et Sophie, ou les Solitaires, and also Les Amours de Lord Edouard.

2. Breakfasted with Messrs: Cutting and Lee. Called on Captain Mackay, and found there a Captain Robison, who had a letter from Mr: King for me. Called on both the Messrs: Willink, but did not see them.— On Messrs: Van Staphorst & Hubbard, both of whom I found.— They have received some late remittances from America. Long walk in the afternoon along the Amstel, on the road to Utrecht. Evening with Cutting and the other American Gentlemen. Mr: Marshall and his family arrived this day.

3. Mr: Damen called on me this forenoon. Is going out of town, as is almost the universal practice of the Amsterdam merchants on Saturdays, or Friday’s. They stay in the Country till Monday. Next Monday being an Holiday, nothing will be done in town untill Tuesday. Went in the afternoon with Lee, to the Jewish Synagogue. Heard their Devotions. There were no women present.— Evening at the french Comedy.— Jenneval, by Mercier; an imitation of George Barnwell; pretty well performed.— Le Tonnelier.

4. Fine day, though cool and windy. Went to dine with Mr: W. Willink at Bosch en Hooven, his Country seat near Haerlem.— Mr: Hubbard, and another Gentleman with his Lady there, whom I did not know.— We had strawberry’s, grapes, and a musk melon at table, all the produce of the garden. The mice had eaten all the peaches, or we should have had some of them.— This is the Dutchman’s magnificence.— The measure of the Lands is by Morgens equal to two of our Acres. Mr: Willink has 34 of them here, and tells me that his meadows would yield him 50 guilders per morgen yearly rent. The value of the Land is more than 1000 guilders a morgen.— Returned to town in the Evening. Called on Mr: & Mrs: Marshall— Our conversation almost learned. Young Marshall takes singularity for genius, and seems to consider ability as consisting in the disclaimer of all authority.— I have seen such men before.— They always have a certain depth; because they exert their faculties of reason, reflection and observation. But they are never very deep, because they depend too much upon themselves. A total disregard of authority, and a servile submission to it are alike unfriendly to all philosophy, and all science.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.subject: Recreation
Westward Exploration and Expansion/Westward Migration/Manifest Destiny

div.p: 5. Holiday— They call it Pentecost, and observe these days more generally here than I imagined or had heretofore remarked.— Writing in the forenoon. After dinner took a long walk with Mr: Cutting; out at the Haerlem gate, and went round the canal beyond the walls, the outer Cingel, to the Dyke in view of the Zuiderzee; upon which we went some way. Returned and passed the Evening, with Cutting, Mr: Vancouver and Marshall, the younger, and Lee. Mr: Vancouver’s brother has made the last voyage round the world, which is soon to be published. He himself is a traveller: a man of information and understanding. Cutting told us of Mr: Jefferson’s instructions to the traveller Ledyard, when he intended to try the passage across from Kamschatka. He was to carry nothing with him; no instruments, no books: nothing that could possibly tempt the avidity of a Savage. But he was to keep the Journal of his travels by pricking it with thorns upon his skin. He had a scale of a foot marked out with indian ink in inches and lines, upon his arm, between the elbow and the wrist. If he met any remarkable mountain or other object of which he wished to know the Latitude, he was to cut him a stick of three feet long, and in the same spot, mark the length of its shadow by the rising and setting sun, and then by the point of intersection drawn from the extremity of the two shadows, he would find the length of the shadow at noon, whence the Latitude might be collected. If he came across a river and wished to measure its width, he was to plant a stick at some station upon the bank, then with another stick horizontally level his eye at the opposite bank: after which turning round his stick, and preserving it at the same angle, take a sight with it at some object on the bank where he stood, and measure the distance, which would of course give him that across the river.— Cutting was in extasies while he told all this.— Poor Ledyard was stopped in his travels at Tobolsk, and afterwards died at Grand Cairo, on another Journey into Abyssinia. But had he pursued his north west road, whatever benefit his success might have procured to mankind, his journal upon his skin would not I think have been worth much.

6. Wrote again in the forenoon. Called twice upon Mr: W. Willink; found him at last after dinner. drew upon Mr: King, and settled some other affairs. Went upon the Exchange.— At the french Play. Le Procureur Arbitre, and Le Jugement de Midas. Found Mrs: Marshall, there; and her husband’s brother; who improves on acquaintance.— House very thin.— Remainder of the Evening and supper at Mr: Hubbard’s, with the two Mr: Willink’s.

7. Cutting went off very early this morning for Paris.— Letters from London by the way of Rotterdam. Answered them. Saw upon the Exchange Mr: J. Willink, Mr: Damen, and Mr: Hubbard. Made the rest of my arrangements for departure. I have now nothing more to do here. Went with Mr: Lee to the play. Tom Jones a Londres, and La Servante Maitresse. Performance tolerable. The weather has been dull, cold and rainy. I have read out my books, and find myself somewhat at a loss for amusement.

8. Mr: Damen called on me this morning and informed me that Mr: Murray had arrived last Evening at the Texel, and might be expected here this night. Visit from Mr: W. Willink who gave me the same information. Clarke called on me after dinner, and we took a walk together without the town. Evening with Lee. Young Marshall came in and launched out upon the corruption of the public Offices and Officers in France till it was after one in the morning.

9. This forenoon arrived Mr: Dandrige, Mr: Murray’s secretary, with Captain Smith the Master of the vessel in which they came. They called on me with Mr: Damen. Towards night Mr: and Mrs: Murray themselves arrived; and I immediately called upon them. I was intimately acquainted with him in the year 1784, but have not seen him since. The lapse of thirteen years is perceptible upon his countenance. Mrs: Murray, I have never before seen. They are both much fatigued, and somewhat unwell from a long and tedious passage North about, and a journey from the Texel here.— Supped with them in their apartment— The Letters and Newspapers, which Mr: Murray brings me kept me up reading till two in the morning.

10. Spent the principal part of the day in conversation with Mr: Murray, upon every subject concerning which he was desirous of information. We made a large party and went to the french comedy in the Evening— Le Conciliateur ou l’homme aimable, a new play by M. de Moustier and l’Epreuve villageoise. The performance was good. Marshall, and Lee, with me late.

11. We made a party this morning, Mr: & Mrs: Murray, Mr: & Mrs: Marshall, Louis Marshall, Mr: Van Couver, Mr: Dandridge, Mr: Lee and myself to visit the little towns of Saardam and Broek, in North-Holland. We crossed the river Y, in a sailboat and on the other side took a carriages which carried us in two hours to Broek. This village is distinguished for its extreme cleanliness. It consists of about 200 families most of which are very wealthy. You would imagine the whole village covered by a single roof. The Houses are all low, very neatly painted. There is a small yard or garden encircled by a fence before their front doors, which are all placed to high from the ground as to require three or four steps of descent. There are however no steps from them. The doors themselves are all never opened except upon two occasions when there is a death or a marriage in the family.— We saw the People coming from church, their dresses were all alike, all black and the customary habiliments of the Dutch Peasants. The women had a little square plate of silver, about the size of the reflecting glass in a mariners quadrant, fastened at each of their temples. The streets are not wide enough for the passage of any carriage drawn by horses or oxen. They are paved throughout with flat bricks, sanded and swept in angles like a floor. In the church, there was nothing remarkable. In the poor house, which we entered we found every thing neat in proportion to the Streets. From thence we went to Saardam, in two hours and an half. There we stopped and dined. This place I had seen before. It is a large town where the principal ship-building is carried on. It would be remarkably neat to any one, not
coming from Broek. But that renders the judgment very fastidious. This is the place where the czar Peter, called the Great, worked as a common ship-carpenter. They shew the house in which he worked.— We went to the Church where we found the Minister preaching to a large and decent auditory. We saw the picture of the woman thrown up by a bull, and delivered of a child in the air, an accident which is said to have happened in this place and has thus been commemorated.— After dinner we returned to Amsterdam, as we came. Evening principally in Mr: Marshall’s apartment.

12. The weather yesterday was so cold and unpleasant, that both the Ladies this day, complain of having yester taken cold.— I intended to have gone on this day to the Hague, but find I cannot engage a place in the Stage. Mr: Murray too expresses a wish to go with me, and we have agreed therefore to proceed in the trackschuyt on Wednesday. Young Marshall, Lee and Clarke with me late this Evening.— Walk in the afternoon with Mr: Murray. Visit of Mr: Van Hemert.

13. Took a long walk this morning with Mr: Murray, out upon the great dike; as we returned we were thoroughly drenched by a heavy shower of rain. At the comedy. Le François a Londres and Azemia ou les Sauvages— Tolerable. The air “Voyage qui le voudra,” sung a second time. Mr: William Willink called on Mr: Murray, and on me.— We supped at Mr: Von Hemert’s. Had something of a large party there. Mr: Fonscuberte the french consul there. I had not known him before.— We were late home, as usual.— Madam Von Hemert very agreeable.

14. At 12 this morning day, with Mr: and Mrs: Murray, and Mr: Dandridge, we took the roof of the treck-schuyt for Haerlem, when we arrived at the place of departure we found the boat, just going, and were obliged to leave our baggage behind, to come on by the next boat, an hour later. When we came to the half-way passage, it was in the midst of an heavy shower of rain: which we were obliged to pass through, as the boat men could not wait. At Haerlem we took a carriage and dined at the golden fleece Inn. While dinner was preparing we went into the Old church to look at the famous large organ, but did not hear it play. As we were entering the door of the Church Mr: Murray and Mr: Dandridge were accosted by a soldier, who enquired in English whether there were any American vessels at Amsterdam about to sail: upon looking into the fellow’s face, I found it was that swindler Cashmore who gave me so much trouble the last fall. I soon sent him about his business, and told the Gentlemen, what impositions he had passed upon me and many others.— At 4 we took the Boat for Leyden, our baggage having previously joined us. At 8 in the Evening we arrived, and were again molested with rain, from the boat to our lodgings at the golden Lion; where we found the weather so cold and damp, that a fire was very comfortable.— I sat up conversing upon various subjects with Mr: Murray till 2 o’clock in the morning.

15. Mr: and Mrs: Murray by the experience of yesterday had got sufficiently weary of conveyance by the treckschuyts, and preferred taking a carriage this morning from Leyden. We arrived at the Hague between one and two o’clock, and they took their lodgings at the Heere Logement.— In the afternoon
Bielfeld called upon me for half an hour.— Visited Mr: Van Leyden, and informed him of the arrival of Mr: Murray. Agreed to introduce him to Mr: Van Leyden, to-morrow morning. Conversation with Mr: Van Leyden upon the subject of the Presents usually made to foreign Ministers when they take leave. I told him that as I shall still hold an Office of trust and profit under the United States, at the time of my departure, an article of the Constitution forbids my acceptance of any present whatever from a foreign Government, and that I wish this obligation on my part may be understood in its proper sense, and not as proceeding from any disrespect to this Government. He then asked whether the consent of Congress could not be obtained, I told him that I could not say how that might be;— He said that in order to avoid the unpleasant appearance of a refusal, it might be left for a future arrangement, until I could write and obtain the consent of congress: I agreed to leave it thus, and that in case I should obtain that consent I can receive the present afterwards.— Mr: Van Leyden is unwell and going out of town— Called afterwards at General Pinckney’s and went with him and his family to the Heeren Logement to see Mr: & Mrs: Murray. Walk in the evening with Mr: Murray, and out late.

16. This morning between 9 and 10. I introduced Mr: Murray and Mr: Dandridge to Mr: Van Leyden, for whom they both had Letters. We told him that we proposed to deliver our Letters of recall and of credence to the President on Monday or Tuesday, he requested me in that case to write to the President naming the day, and requesting to know the hour that would suit him, to which I agreed and accordingly did, in the course of the day.— We dined with General Pinckney. Evening at Mr: Veerman’s; and took a walk with Madam.

17. Called this forenoon upon General Pinckney, found Mr: Murray there. The General read to us his late correspondence from Paris.— Preparing for my departure. In the Evening at Mr: Veerman’s. Engaged to go with Madam to-morrow and introduce her to Mrs: Murray Called at Mrs: Murray’s and informed her of this Engagement.

18. Went this forenoon with Madam Veerman, and introduced her to Mrs: Murray. Afterwards walked with her to the house in the wood. We dined with Mr: Murray at the Heeren Logement. Walk and conversation with him late in the Evening. Received this day the answer from the President of the Assembly Vitringa, that he will receive us on Tuesday between 10 and 11. in the morning.

19. Spent the day again in preparations for my departure. Called on Mr: Murray in the afternoon. At Mr: Noël’s. Found Madam was gone out. He told me that the french Plenipotentiaries for Peace with England were appointed. The Congress to be held at Lille. Remainder of the Evening at Madam May’s.

20. At ten this morning, I called upon Mr: Murray, and went with him to the Hall of audience of the National Assembly, where we were received by the President Mr: Vitringa. After introducing to him, Mr: Murray, I delivered my letters of recall, together with a letter to the National Assembly, taking leave of them conformably to my instructions. Mr: Murray then delivered his credentials. The President after the usual compliments to me upon my departure, and to Mr: Murray upon his arrival, assured us that he would lay our papers before the Assembly immediately upon their meeting. After a short conversation upon indifferent subjects we withdrew.— Called on Madam Veerman, and accompanied her to the french Comedy. La bonne mere— L’ami de la maison, and La fête de campagne. Walk with Madam Veerman after the play.

21. Dined at Mr: Van Staphorst’s, with our American circle, and Mr: Schimmelpenninck and Mr: De Vos van Steenwyk, who is going as Minister Plenipotentiary from here to Paris.— After dinner we took a walk to the house in the wood, and went over it.— Evening at Mr: Noël’s, at a little party of music. The corps Diplomatique all there. The Ladies sung and performed upon the forte piano, very well. Met Mr: Lestevenon there.

22. Called this morning with Mr: Murray upon Mr: Lestevenon, and had some conversation with him. Busy the principal part of the day in packing up.— In the afternoon at Mr: Veerman’s. Proposed to Madam, to go to the french Comedy, but she declined. Evening rainy, which prevented us from walking. Mrs: Veerman entertained me with singing and playing upon the forte-piano.

23. Mr: Murray called on me, and we went to visit Mr: Goldberg, but found him gone to Amsterdam. General Pinckney and his family; Mr: & Mrs: Murray & Mr: Dandridge, and Mr: & Mrs: Veerman dined with us.— Evening at Mr: Murray’s.— Mr: Lestevenon called to see me this forenoon. The agent of the National Assembly, also, Mr: Slicher, came and made me the compliments of the Assembly upon my departure. He likewise carried to Mr: Murray the resolution of the Assembly recognizing him as Minister Resident of the United States.

24. Went between 11 and 12 this morning to the Heeren Logement to take Mr: Murray: found him however at Macqueen’s. We went round together and paid all the diplomatic visits. I to take leave, and Mr: Murray, by way of introduction. We left cards every where. After this we went to General Pinckney’s lodgings. He had some interesting intelligence from France and from America. with the speech of the President of the U.S. at the opening of the Session of Congress on the 16th: of last month.— At Mr: Veerman’s in the afternoon. Long Walk with Madam to Loosduynen, and returned round by the way of the Downs. This in all probability closes our walks.

25. Visit this forenoon from M. d’Anduaga, and M. Sönanez. Called on Mr: Murray. Dined with Count Löwenhielm in the Country. Home and wrote several Letters. Latter part of the Evening at the Baron de Schubart’s. Found Mr: Bosset there.— Conversation pleasant— I received this morning notice from Rotterdam, that the vessel in which we have engaged to take our passage to London, will be ready on Wednesday morning. It is sooner than I expected and of course hurries the remainder of my time here.

26. Called on Mr: Van Leyden to obtain a Passport from the Committee of Marine to protect my baggage against capture. He engaged to procure it, and sent it in the Evening after having returned my visit in the course of the day. Met Mr: Murray who was going to look at the old Hotel, belonging to the United States, which he has determined to inhabit. Went with him and took a view all over the House. The first time I have been in it since the year 1784. It revived many recollections which have been nearly effaced by the length of the time. Very much employed through the day. An hour or two in the Evening at Mr: Veerman’s. Walk once more with his Lady.

27. By dint of great industry, completed by dinner time my Packing up, to go off to-morrow morning. Dined at Mr: Veerman’s, with Genl: Pinckney, and Mr: Murray and their families. Took leave of Veerman and his family.— Remainder of the Evening, delivering cards to take leave.

28. Mr: Murray bore us company to Rotterdam.— Left the Hague in the boat for Delft at half past seven. Arrived at Rotterdam at 11. Found as we expected, the vessel not ready to go. Mr: Murray returned, by the boat at 6. Mr: Havart called on us. I went with him by his invitation to the Country seat, just out of the town, opposite the Plantagie where his father in Law, his mother and Sister reside.— It is a very pleasant seat, with a fine garden, both for fruits and flowers. The plantagie is a small wood along the banks of the Maes, laid out in walks, and belonging to the town. We returned and supped at Mr: Havart’s in town. Met there Mr: Fettiplace an American, & a Dutch Gentleman.— Havart is a bachelor.

29. Yesterday, our Captain was determined to go to day. He now thinks of going to-morrow. Mr: Crawford called on me this morning, and sent me some English news-papers, to the 24th: We dined with him. Mr: Bickercarton the Swedish Consul was there.— Mr: Crawford gave me a couple of his pamphlets upon the subject of finance, and particularly the finances of England. Conversation with him on the subject. He is a great Enemy to the system of a sinking fund, and in general to Mr: Pitt’s financeering.— He is ingenious and has many good ideas: but I think he does not well connect them together. They are confused and obscure in his Doctrine of equivalents especially.— He has some good pictures, being something of an amateur. Took a walk round the town.— Mr: Beeldemaker called to take leave of me this Evening.

30. We embarked this morning on board the Alexander & Alexander, under Prussian colours, and sailed from the wharf at about eight. But the wind being unfavourable, we could get down no further than Maassluys, where we came to Anchor, landed, and passed the remainder of the Day.
Day. None, while travelling.
